docTitle.titlePart: Statement on the Election of John. F. Kennedy

sourceDesc.bibl: "If Kennedy Wins, Mrs. Sanger is Going to Quit US,"Milwaukee Journal 07/06/60

doc.headNote: Sanger's comments on the possible Kennedy election were picked up again + reported in the Press after Nov. 10, when she added that she would wait until the end of the first year before deciding whether to move out. See "Mrs. Sanger Staying," New York TimesNov. 10, 1960, p. 39

docBody.head: If Kennedy Wins, Mrs. Sanger Is Going to Quit US
docBody.p: Mrs. Margaret Sanger, crusader for birth control, says she will "find another place to live" if Senator John F. Kennedy becomes president.
Mrs. Sanger said she was opposed to Kennedy because of his religion.
"In my estimation a Roman Catholic is neither Democrat nor Republican.
"Nor American, nor Chinese; he is a Roman Catholic," Mrs. Sanger said.
Mrs. Sanger is here on a vacation from her Tuscan (Ariz.) home.
She told a reported that a Roman Catholic at the head of the country would "make impossible America's most important contribution to world peace--the dissemination of birth control information."
She is the founder and president emeritus of the Planned Parenthood federation.
